awd_abstract_narration:
The Shanks Workshop on Complex Differential Geometry will take place on March 2-3, 2018, at Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN. The workshop brings together leading researchers with different backgrounds, but common research  interests in the area of complex differential geometry. This research area uses techniques from complex analysis, differential geometry and algebraic geometry, and the real insight of these theories is highlighted when all these facets merge together and relations between them are established. The main goal of the workshop is to promote these interactions and initiate new projects and collaborations. This meeting is expected to be highly beneficial to graduate students and junior mathematicians as they will have the opportunity to interact with experts in the field in a friendly, open to discussions environment.

Complex differential geometry is an area with deep roots and very rapid and diverse advances. The proposed workshop brings together researchers using a variety of techniques which focus on one main problem: understanding canonical metrics in complex geometry. The workshop is intended to present recent progress in the study of complete Calabi-Yau manifolds and Ricci solitons with prescribed asymptotic behavior, Sasaki-Einstein geometry, extremal Kahler metrics, moduli space of Kahler metrics and the relations with stability, and generalizations to Hermitian geometry. For more details, see the workshop webpage at https://my.vanderbilt.edu/shankscdg/.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The workshop "Complex Differential Geometry" took place at Vanderbilt University on March 2-3, 2018. The award partially supported the travel expenses of the participants with priority given to junior researchers and member of under-represented groups.

Complex differential geometry is an area with deep roots and very rapid and diverse advances. Its development relies on a multitude of techniques from complex analysis, differential geometry and algebraic geometry, and the real insight into these areas is revealed when all these facets merge together, and the relations between them is established. The workshop featured presentations on the recent progress in the study of complete Calabi-Yau manifolds or Kahler-Ricci solitons, as well as new advances in the study of Kahler metrics of constant scalar curvature and Sasaki-Einstein geometry. The central goal of the workshop was to promote these interactions and initiate new projects and collaborations.

The workshop featured 13 high quality presentations, out of which two were given by female mathematicians, and four by junior mathematicians (assistant professors). In total, there were 29 participants, which included 17 graduate students. The friendly, small setting provided an ideal environment for junior mathematicians to promote their work and interact with more senior researchers.

The funds which remained unspent were used during the no-cost extensions to partially support the organizations of other workshops in the area of complex geometry  at Vanderbilt University: "Real Enumerative Geometry and Beyond", March 6-7, 2020, and "Interactions in Complex Geometry" on December 11-12, 2021. The two workshops had 13 speakers, out of whom five were female mathematicians (one senior professor, two graduate students and two postdocs).

The workshops fulfilled their main goals of: presenting state-of-art research, stimulating new collaborative projects, promoting early career mathematicians and members of the under-represented groups, and providing a friendly, stimulating environment for discussions.

 


Last Modified: 07/18/2022
Modified by: Ioana Suvaina
